toc_entry.title: Tea For Texas
toc_entry.description: Can Texans be won over to the antique tradition of tea and little sandwiches in the afternoon? Dallas’ and Houston’s new gilded hotels are counting on it.

toc_entry.title: I Am the Greatest Cook In the World
toc_entry.description: And I’m telling you, if you can’t batter it, fry it, spike it with chiles, or bathe it in buttermilk, it’s not worth your time.

toc_entry.title: Charlie Brooks’ Last Words
toc_entry.description: Charlie Brooks was the first man to die by lethal injection, but everyone wondered whether he or his partner was the real murderer. In his last days, Brooks answered that, and other questions.

toc_entry.title: Lyndon’s Lincoln
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: Can you picture Lbj in a Datsun?

toc_entry.title: The Year Everything Changed
toc_entry.description: If you think Texas is pretty much the same as it was ten years ago, you’re wrong. Nineteen seventy-three remade the state overnight.

toc_entry.title: Main Street
toc_entry.description: It’s Houston's driveway, a twenty-mile kaleidoscope of bankers, punkers, strippers, surgeons, students, grackles, and cars.

toc_entry.title: Other Main Streets
toc_entry.description: They’re where you went to get your hair cut or to see a picture show or to watch the squirrels on the courthouse lawn.

toc_entry.title: NEXT TO GOLDINESS
toc_entry.subtitle: Movies
toc_entry.description: Gandhi presents its title character as all but a god and India as all but a paradise. Starstruck is a lark; Sophie’s Choice is a letdown.

toc_entry.title: As Good As Her Word
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: Texas women write about crop dusters and frozen custard and the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport in the encouraging new anthology Her Work. Life Sentences, though, is a flimsy feminist exercise.

toc_entry.title: The Cassandra Of Crude
toc_entry.subtitle: Business
toc_entry.description: Dale Stejfes can predict the future of the oil business. So why do the majors turn a deaf ear? Because, says Stejfes, the news is all bad.

toc_entry.title: Standing Room Opera
toc_entry.subtitle: Classical Music
toc_entry.description: Texas opera lovers would have ended the season happily just having seen a lively Rosenkavalier, a magical Rheingold, and a fiery Wozzeck. But then the Houston Grand Opera's Pagliacci came along and took their breath away.

toc_entry.title: Thunder Claps
toc_entry.subtitle: Popular Music
toc_entry.description: The Fabulous Tliunderbirds storm away on a new album that shows why they’re Texas hardiest rhythm and blues band. Eight more releases capture everything from mandolin picking to Balinese monkey chants.

toc_entry.title: The Roar Of the Crowd
toc_entry.description: End of the line for a cop, a coach, quitters, and the Confederate Air Force

toc_entry.title: Touts
toc_entry.description: Sing along, turn around, dip in.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A selective guide to entertainment and events of more than usual interest

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: The unhealthy politics of emergency medicine; according an accordionist his due; sucking it up for Lite beer; the condo boom that went bust.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: Treasure hunters want state booty; Republicans aren’t so hot about Phil Gramm; there s hope for Texans with money in Mexico; Texas newspapers worry about Usa Today.
